results.title: I am a singer
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission and Megan Heyward
results.brief_description: This award winning interactive CD-Rom weaves a fragmentary narrative about an amnesiac famed for her singing. Exploring notions of performance, autobiography and memory this is an intriguing and compelling story in which the viewer helps to reconstruct the events of a life lived through song.

results.title: Strange cities
results.brief_description: ‘Strange cities’ is an experimental interactive multimedia work that tells of the survival of the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions by two Russian exiles. It draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg to explore memory, transience and the urban imagination. It is an experimental interactive multimedia work authored for CD-Rom release and exhibition. Through the disclosure of evidence, Sasha dreams, discovers, remembers the exilic identity of her grandparents Xenia and Sergei Ermolaeff (a composer and orchestra leader) in fragments and traces of their music, memories, personal effects and photographs, in their struggle to survive the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions. The inspiration for the work is a tune of the same name - a musical illustration, an imaginary vision of old Shanghai, Chinese metropolis, and International Settlement, conjuring mythic, filmic, musical and personal images of the city port. The ‘Strange cities’ musical score1 written by Alexander Vertinsky, Serge Ermoll and Ira Bloch, was first performed by a jazz orchestra of White Russian emigres in the cabarets of the International Settlement of Shanghai, China in the 1930’s and 40’s. ‘Strange cities’ draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg. Coined capital of the international underworld, the city of Shanghai became a seductively strange locale symbolized in the Western imagination, in reality the city was most often the final port of call for political refugees.

results.title: The Cute Machine
results.brief_description:
‘The Cute machine’ is an exploration into the morphology of cute characterisation and iconography and its relationship to the biological world, seeking to analyse this ‘Cute ideal’ by correlating it with the Zoological process known as Neoteny

The CD contains two sections that had already been exhibited as installations (Sorry! and Activity Station) but were then adapted to a screen version. The remaining sections elaborate on the themes of cute iconography and its analysis.

The Cute Machine proposes an environment where cute iconography and user friendliness have rampantly accelerated, and reduced computer interface design to the look and sophistication of an infant toy, while also taking the premise, Cute = young to the extreme, where the ‘Cutest’, becomes an abstracted mutation of the original sentiment.

results.title: Patterns
results.brief_description: Patterns is a documentary which explores issues to do with politics, work, art and women’s history. A number of threads are woven between the sweatshop and the art gallery, the glory box and the political banner, bourgeois femininity and the question: should a feminist knit? An incisive and kaleidoscopic exploration of needlework and its place in women’s lives.

results.title: Fifty fifty
results.creator_credit: Carole Sklan and Face Value Productions
results.brief_description: Flashing back and forth between the Fifties and the Eighties, the film explores with wit and panache the political and social connections between the two eras, converting a potential nostalgia trip into a sharply focused but entertaining analysis of the pressure placed on men and women then and now.

results.title: One Day Soon
results.brief_description: A production that shows how handicapped people can live independent lives and how they cope with their unique situation. This video has won the Television Society Penguin Award and the Mobile Award.

results.title: Mongrel's funeral
results.creator_credit: Peter Maguire, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A small country community is drawn together by the death of “Mongrel” in an accident. But it’s not until his mates gather in the pub in their “Sunday best” to bolster their courage for the funeral, that they are able to express their real sorrow. Conveniently missing the church service, they give Mongrel a send-off in their own way. Cast includes Sheila Florance, Reg Evans, Charlie Sandford, Neil Robbins, Andrew Klipple, Neil Modra, Alec Maguire and Keith Johnson. (Award: Winner Diploma of Merit, Melbourne Film Festival 1987)

results.title: Wildlife of the River Valley
results.brief_description: A program that presents a unique view of the enormous variety of wildlife that lives in the Bellinger River Valley, situated halfway between Sydney and Brisbane on the east coast of Australia. This is a brightly paced, entertaining and informative documentary that can be enjoyed by audiences of all ages.

results.title: Winners: Room to Move
results.creator_credit: John Duigan, Richard Mason, Julia Overton, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Carol is a top runner, coached by her father day and night. Then she makes friends with Angie, the new girl at school whose punk looks haven’t made her very popular. Angie introduces Carol to the wonderful world of dance, but Carol’s father won’t let her do anything that conflicts with her track-training. Parental pressure is tough on Carol who wants to succeed. She rebels and plans a new life for herself, but the all-important race is coming up and Carol has to give it all she’s got.

Cast includes Nicole Kidman, Terence Donovan and Alyssa Cook.

results.title: Winners: Top Kid
results.creator_credit: Carl Schultz, Jane Scott, Bob Ellis, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Gary is a bright boy - a bit too bright for his own good, as the other kids try to prove by beating him up regularly after school. Then he goes on a quiz show and suddenly fame and fortune are within his reach… until they start to rig the show and Gary has to make a very difficult decision.

Cast includes Emil Minty, Harold Hopkins, Michelle Fawdon and Garry McDonald.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carl Schultz, Jane Scott, Bob Ellis, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children’s Television Foundation
